docs.lead_paragraph: A few months ago, a representative of an organization that calls itself Right of Way urged me to ''question the ongoing clampdown on children's mobility and autonomy in the name of safety.'' The writer was objecting to a New York City Council proposal to require children 14 and younger to wear helmets while riding those now-popular scooters. How, I would like to know, does wearing a helmet -- a good protective one, Phantom by Bell, costs a mere $15 at Sears, Kmart and Wal-Mart -- impede a child's ''mobility and autonomy''? What it does do is protect that child's brain from an injury that could result in a concussion, a fractured skull or even death.

headline.main: Save a Child's Brain: Require a Helmet

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on need for protective equipment and safety precautions when children play baseball or softball, ride bicycles or scooters or engage in water sports; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers believe they may now be able to explain what happens to mountain climbers struck down by a condition popularly known as HAPE. The illness, high altitude pulmonary edema, can occur among climbers who go beyond 8,250 feet, especially those who ascend too rapidly. It is characterized by extreme listlessness, fluid in the lungs, sleeplessness, coughing up blood and sometimes disorientation. It is sometimes fatal.
docs.abstract: Researchers report that high altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) occurs in mountain climbers when elevated pressure in capillaries allow water to accumulate in lungs; links HAPE to oxygen atmosphere at high altitude, and not to leaks in lung wall; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Researchers believe they may now be able to explain what happens to mountain climbers struck down by a condition popularly known as HAPE.    The illness, high altitude pulmonary edema, can occur among climbers who go beyond 8,250 feet, especially...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gerald Moreno was thrilled when his doctor told him he was responding wonderfully to his H.I.V. drug cocktail, which included a powerful new protease inhibitor. Then the physician delivered the other news. Despite Mr. Moreno's apparent improvement, tests revealed that he had a second major illness, hepatitis C, which can lead to liver cancer, cirrhosis and, in some cases, death.

headline.main: Hepatitis C Poses New Threat to Many With AIDS

docs.abstract: Hepatitis C has become No. 1 cause of death among people with HIV; treatment outlook of hepatitis C has improved markedly in recent years, but the only hope for many patients is liver transplant, an option routinely denied to people with AIDS virus; studies indicate that HIV can greatly speed progression of hepatitis C; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: You are taught, when you train to be a psychiatrist, not to give advice. Instead, you must explore with patients their motives, needs and wishes and let them arrive at their own conclusions. Thus goes the professional credo. But one never really knows what goes on between any other psychiatrist and patient. Psychiatric practice is more secreted from scrutiny than any other medical specialty. Rarely are there the collegial interactions with regard to a patient that most doctors expect and enjoy.
docs.abstract: Anna Fels article says psychotherapists sometimes break the rule about not giving advice to patients, and do it to good effect; says even therapists who would never directly give advice can steer a patient in a certain direction with a gesture, sound or the most neutral-sounding word (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Painfully Shy: How to Overcome Social Anxiety and Reclaim Your Life,'' by Barbara G. Markway and Gregory P. Markway, Thomas Dunne Books, St. Martin's Press, $23.95. Shyness, as we generally know it, implies a timid reserve, a quality perhaps best expressed in the term wallflower. But what the authors -- husband and wife and clinical psychologists -- describe here is a far more serious affliction, one that creates intense physical distress and mental anguish that are sometimes severe enough to put some people at greater risk for depression, substance abuse and even suicide.

headline.main: What to Do When Shyness Becomes Disabling

docs.lead_paragraph: When a young child has an epileptic seizure for the first time, many parents share the same worries: Will it happen again? And will it be worse next time? A new study may lay some of the fears to rest, at least for many parents.

headline.main: Length of Child's First Seizure Is Telling

docs.abstract: Evidence suggests that if a child's first epileptic seizure is short, any subsequent ones will be short too (S)
docs.snippet: When a young child has an epileptic seizure for the first time, many parents share the same worries: Will it happen again? And will it be worse next time?    A new study may lay some of the fears to rest, at least for many parents.

docs.lead_paragraph: Getting people to quit smoking may be hard, but discouraging them from starting, at least when they are young, may be as simple as raising the taxes on cigarettes. A new study reports a link between the price of a pack of cigarettes and the likelihood that a teenager will start smoking. After surveying a total of 12,000 8th- and 10th-grade students for seven years and taking into account the local price for cigarettes, the researchers concluded that a 10 percent increase in price decreased the odds of teenagers' starting smoking by as much as 10 percent.

headline.main: When Smoking Is a Matter of Money

docs.abstract: Study suggests that 10 percent increase in price of cigarettes decreases odds of teenagers' starting smoking by as much as 10 percent; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Add cave-ins to the list of known beach hazards like sunburn, drowning and shark attacks. A recent report in The Journal of the American Medical Association made note of a little-known danger associated with digging large holes in dry sand. The correspondents, Bradley A. Maron of Brown University and Dr. Barry J. Maron of the Minneapolis Heart Institute Foundation, said they found four cases from 1997 to 2000 in which people died and three close calls, when the holes collapsed and the people were buried. They likened the risks to those of professional excavations.

headline.main: Surfside Danger: Big Holes in Dry Sand

docs.abstract: Collapse of big holes dug in dry beach sand is blamed for four deaths and three close calls between 1997 and 2000; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Add cave-ins to the list of known beach hazards like sunburn, drowning and shark attacks.    A recent report in The Journal of the American Medical Association made note of a little-known danger associated with digging large holes in dry sand. The...

docs.lead_paragraph: The rewards of epidemiologic investigations include identifying new ways that old diseases can be transmitted, recognizing new health hazards and finding new ideas for reducing the incidence of preventable diseases. And although epidemiologists solve many outbreaks, they are stumped by others, or hampered in other ways, like hospital lawyers who do not allow them to interview affected patients. Such rewards and frustrations were evident in reports by epidemiologists from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and state health departments at the 50th annual meeting of the Epidemic Intelligence Service here this week.

headline.main: The Rewards, and the Roadblocks, of Medical Sleuthing

docs.abstract: Annual meeting of Epidemic Intelligence Service in Atlanta hears reports from epidemiologists on their successes and frustrations in trying to find new ways that old diseases can be transmitted, recognize new health hazards and find new ideas for reducing incidence of preventable diseases; cases involve tularemia (rabbit fever), typhoid, SIDS, caterpillar allergy, flue vaccine and birth defects (M)
docs.snippet: The rewards of epidemiologic investigations include identifying new ways that old diseases can be transmitted, recognizing new health hazards and finding new ideas for reducing the incidence of preventable diseases. And although epidemiologists solve...

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent years, a product known as a nasal dilator has become popular among professional and recreational athletes who believe that by improving their breathing, they will improve their performance. Now a new study suggests that the product, which resembles a piece of tape worn on the bridge of the nose, may not be particularly helpful. The article in Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise was based on a study of 14 people ages 20 to 29.

headline.main: Of Pain, Gain and Tape on Your Nose

docs.abstract: Study casts doubt on whether nasal dilators, which resemble pieces of tape worn on bridge of nose, improve athletic performance by increasing air flow through nose (S)
